title: Is it legal to add a collection/late fee after 7 months past due of an invoice payment?
question: If there is no contract in place that specifies late fees? My company is European and not based in America and I am billing in Euros.
answers:
You should consult with an experienced commercial collection attorney or debt collection agency, before you make legal mistakes that can result in a harassment lawsuit. If the collection agency has experience with the collection laws of the EU, that would be better. Consumer debts in California do not permit collection of fees and charges that are not specified in the contract. Your posting did not specify commercial or consumer, but I assume this is primarily a commercial contract.

No. If it is a consumer account, it would be a violation of the federal Fair Debt Collection Practices Act as well as state statutes. You may charge interest at no more than the statutory maximum rate. In California, the maximum is 10% per annum simple interest. (If you were a qualified financial institution, such as a bank or payday lender, you could charge more.)

If you want to rewrite your contract, the specified late fee must qualify as liquidated damages, and not be a penalty.

Probably not. Generally, to charge a late fee, both sides need to be on the same page that a late fee "could" be charged. In short, whatever agreement you have with this party, the agreement must specify that a late fee can be charged and the amount. As for collection fees, the same rule essentially applies. The contract must specify that collection fees can be added. However, with collection fees, you may have more variability, but adding collection fees without a contract saying you can, can generally only happen in the context of a lawsuit. And only then if the jurisdiction allows it.

Let's look at the big picture, this party hasn't paid you for 7 months, do you really think a late fee is going to change that?
